subject: Ensure python libs are linked to service venvs consistently
messages: [{'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-09-07 18:36:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-09-07 21:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to osa-py3'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-09 07:16:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-09-09 14:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-07 18:36:14.000000000', 'message': "Ensure python libs are linked to service venvs consistently

Several different libraries are linked and some had hardcoded python2.7
paths, which are now auto-detected.

In addition, the detected python interpreter is always used rather than
sometimes being hardcoded to 'python'.

Change-Id: Ibe512c614e1a830b7b160e45c970b953a4d08e23
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure python libs are linked to service venvs consistently

Several different libraries are linked and some had hardcoded python2.7
paths, which are now auto-detected.

In addition, the detected python interpreter is always used rather than
sometimes being hardcoded to 'python'.

Change-Id: Ibe512c614e1a830b7b160e45c970b953a4d08e23

subject: Remove skip of test_project_get_equals_list
messages:
[{'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-24 17:32:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-24 19:19:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2019-09-06 18:10:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Now we don't need this patch because of the latest https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678379/

Otherwise we might want to add a key 'options' to the test, but Tempest is used for stable branches which don't support the feature on Keystone side.
So it takes more time before all stable branches which are supported by Tempest provide the key."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-09-09 16:36:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

i'll go ahead and abandon. we should have a way to move things forward and add options for specific branches/releases forward so we can avoid regressions."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-09-09 16:36:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-24 17:32:34.000000000', 'message': "Remove skip of test_project_get_equals_list

Remove the skip of test_project_get_equals_list with update for the
new 'options' field. Keystone does not and does not (currently) plan
to support microversions. This reflects the change to the response
keystone has for the project objects.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678379/
Related-Bug: #1807751
Change-Id: Ifad8377ca36348b99b96fe7bfcdcd157de3e4e14
"}, {'created': '2019-08-24 19:19:22.000000000', 'message': "Remove skip of test_project_get_equals_list

Remove the skip of test_project_get_equals_list with update for the
new 'options' field. Keystone does not and does not (currently) plan
to support microversions. This reflects the change to the response
keystone has for the project objects.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678322/
Related-Bug: #1807751
Change-Id: Ifad8377ca36348b99b96fe7bfcdcd157de3e4e14
"}]
commit_message:
Remove skip of test_project_get_equals_list

Remove the skip of test_project_get_equals_list with update for the
new 'options' field. Keystone does not and does not (currently) plan
to support microversions. This reflects the change to the response
keystone has for the project objects.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678322/
Related-Bug: #1807751
Change-Id: Ifad8377ca36348b99b96fe7bfcdcd157de3e4e14

commit_message:
Color themes for HTML view

Supports `theme` query parameter with values `legacy` (the color scheme
as it existed before this change), `monochrome` (all black & white), and
`solarized` (see [1]).

NOTE: Currently you can't get sev filters *and* non-legacy theme by
clicking; you have to type in the querystring by hand.  This may be
fixed later.

[1] http://ethanschoonover.com/solarized

Change-Id: Iddfd10970d1e34be6d4d8c917838052a2f5b6607

commit_message:
Update to newer jsonschema in upper-constraints.txt

We have jsonschema capped at a fairly old version. Other than some
specific releases, it looks like keeping it below 3.0 was added in
I943fd68b9fab3bce1764305a5058df5339470757 without really any explanation
why.

Spot checking a few repos seems to be fine with the latest versions of
this lib. Removing restrictions on it to see if the current version can
be used.

Change-Id: Id56690ba6881a9b3ef6a65065249d874bfb8f2fa
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
keystone: Fix sample config generation

oslo-config-generator needs access to the keystone module
itself. Otherwise there are sections missing in the sample config file.

Change-Id: Iaf3108e2af3474e1088ca1832794fe883ba8e011

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-05-08 22:25:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Please consider naming the resource 'floating ip port forward'.

The create and set commands should look as identical as possible where they have the same options.

The 'internal_port_id' attribute is unfortunately named and is confusing to users, it needs to have a name that distinguishes it from the TCP/UDP port numbers.  Elsewhere in the OSC network commands we just use --port.  That may also be confusing but at least it would be consistent."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-08 23:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-08 23:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (9 comments)
 > 
 > Please consider naming the resource 'floating ip port forward'.
 > 
 > The create and set commands should look as identical as possible
 > where they have the same options.
 > 
 > The 'internal_port_id' attribute is unfortunately named and is
 > confusing to users, it needs to have a name that distinguishes it
 > from the TCP/UDP port numbers.  Elsewhere in the OSC network
 > commands we just use --port.  That may also be confusing but at
 > least it would be consistent.

"floating ip port forward" is not the neutron API defined name.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-08 23:28:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-08 23:28:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-05-09 00:18:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

OSC does not necessarily use the exact names used in the REST APIs.  We value user consistency over matching the REST API exactly'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-05-14 08:33:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Could you follow Dean's advise? The naming in OSC commands do not necessarily match names in the neutron API. Consistency among OSC commands is more important."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-14 09:01:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi guys, sorry for the late reply, I'm on it."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-14 10:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

After some refactoring work I'd like to say we should not add such inconsistence.
Firstly, we have the SDK resource definition:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/616710/5/openstack/network/v2/port_forwarding.py
It is named "floating_ip_port_forwarding".
And, for the current OSC client, that inconsistent resource name does not make sense to users especially when they feel confusing about some resources. 
```what does the "server" mean? It is the nova instance, or the compute host? Or something else?```
This is one most popular question people asked.
What's more, we have some resource already have the consistent name, such as, port, network, router. So IMO, it is OK to add a new one.
Finally, if you guys still think this is not acceptable, maybe we should raise this to the mail list to find a more reasonable name for it. And then refactor all the code includeing neutron, openstack-sdk and here, to align with that.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-05-14 10:32:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 20147, 'date': '2019-05-21 04:55:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-21 13:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

This also needs a docs page.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-08-27 22:08:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Also, I still strongly prefer that the resource be named 'floating ip port forward'  Another option that is more of a parallel to security groups would be to use 'floating ip forward rule'.

Using the '-ing' suffix in a resource name does not feel correct to me.  And yes 'floating ip' violates this, we are stuck with that one, it does not make it OK (to me) to make new ones..."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-27 23:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> Also, I still strongly prefer that the resource be named 'floating
 > ip port forward'  Another option that is more of a parallel to
 > security groups would be to use 'floating ip forward rule'.
 > 
 > Using the '-ing' suffix in a resource name does not feel correct to
 > me.  And yes 'floating ip' violates this, we are stuck with that
 > one, it does not make it OK (to me) to make new ones...

As we discussed this before, SDK already named this as "forwarding", CLI and SDK are directly for user. So a consistent resource name makes sense to me.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-08-28 00:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

The name of a resource in any other piece of software is not binding.  There are literally dozens of places where OSC names for objects do not match names used in the REST API or the Python API or the SDK or the project CLIs.  I would also suggest that the vast majority of OSC users will never look at the SDK.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-28 01:39:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

> The name of a resource in any other piece of software is not
 > binding.  There are literally dozens of places where OSC names for
 > objects do not match names used in the REST API or the Python API
 > or the SDK or the project CLIs.  I would also suggest that the vast
 > majority of OSC users will never look at the SDK.

We are talking about OpenStack right? Both SDK and CLI are supplied for OpenStack projects users, for the commands we are adding here now, are for one same project Neutron. We all know there already has inconsistence between OSC and project APIs. But that does not make sense to users, IMO, for this approach here, we can make it consistent, no much complex problems prevent us to achive that.
For OpenStack users, they use both OSC and SDK to develop their own cloud applications. Mostly, OSC users and SDK users are the same group. They can see such inconsistence.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-08-28 04:42:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I disagree with nearly everything in that statement.  Are you aware of how many places OSC uses different names for things than the underlying libraries or APIs?  For example, about half of OpenStack APIs use the word 'metadata' and the other half use 'property'.  OSC uses only 'property' to refer to these attributes everywhere.

The consistency promise that OSC makes to its users is in its own set of commands, not with anything else in OpenStack.  It has been this way since the very first time I outlined the command set for  Compute, Image and Volume.  The value of this has been tested twice with user studies in addition to the direct feedback we get.

The rules for the user facing parts of OSC are strict for a reason.  If you want to let developers do whatever they please, you see the results in the project libraries and CLIs.  That is exactly why OSC exists."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-28 07:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> I disagree with nearly everything in that statement.  Are you aware
 > of how many places OSC uses different names for things than the
 > underlying libraries or APIs?  For example, about half of OpenStack
 > APIs use the word 'metadata' and the other half use 'property'. 
 > OSC uses only 'property' to refer to these attributes everywhere.
 > 
 > The consistency promise that OSC makes to its users is in its own
 > set of commands, not with anything else in OpenStack.  It has been
 > this way since the very first time I outlined the command set for 
 > Compute, Image and Volume.  The value of this has been tested twice
 > with user studies in addition to the direct feedback we get.
 > 
 > The rules for the user facing parts of OSC are strict for a reason.
 >  If you want to let developers do whatever they please, you see the
 > results in the project libraries and CLIs.  That is exactly why OSC
 > exists.

Actually we are talking about to make new commands, the old behaviors, aka that inconsistent-names, do not influence us to make new consistent command name. The history of that inconsistences should make small relevance to new commands.
We now have one and only one Floating IP "Port Forwarding" resource, and neutron API [1], SDK [2], even neuron object [3] all have the same name. It is an official OpenStack network resource. So I could not find a reason to make an inconsistent command name here. Again, we can make it consistent now, so we should do that.
Otherwise maybe OSC needs an official naming rule for the developers to follow:
"you should name your command like this, not that, no need to align the project API or resource name, balala..."
Or we already have that?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html#floating-ips-port-forwarding
[2] https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/network/v2/port_forwarding.py#L16
[3] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/objects/port_forwarding.py#L31'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-08-28 13:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-fip-port-forwardings.html

Dean - I would have to disagree as well.  The Neutron feature is for port forwarding - it's in the spec, API def, code, and doc I linked above.  While I agree it doesn't exactly roll off the tongue, it is technically correct to say we're creating a floating IP port forwarding entry.  The exact naming was debated when we added the support, I think changing OSC would cause confusion since "port forward" is not the same thing.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-28 13:38:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-28 13:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This also needs a docs page.

Done'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-28 13:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-08-28 23:40:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-08-29 01:38:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30156, 'date': '2019-08-29 03:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1

+1 for the patch itself with no opinion on forward v. forwarding.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2019-08-29 07:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-08-29 11:57:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-08-30 09:32:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-09-09 14:08:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add floating IP Port Forwarding commands

Add following commands:
  floating ip port forwarding create
  floating ip port forwarding delete
  floating ip port forwarding list
  floating ip port forwarding set
  floating ip port forwarding show

Closes-Bug: #1811352
Change-Id: I6a5642e8acce28fc830410d4fa3180597b862761

Where are you getting your numbers from, 45mins doesn't reflect reality. You can check on openstack-health:

http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health/#/test/devstack

it's averaging about 18min. So the current numbers are wrong. Probably putting between 15 and 20 would be better."}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2017-02-07 18:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We should also consider updating the "slow node" marker: https://github.com/openstack-infra/devstack-gate/blob/master/devstack-vm-gate.sh#L708-L710'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2017-02-07 19:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Alright, I guess more like "30" would be better. I was able to find a 29 minute stack on the first patch I looked at: http://logs.openstack.org/90/424890/17/check/gate-octavia-v1-dsvm-scenario-multinode-nv/5f274ec/console.html#_2017-02-07_09_53_06_827716'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2017-02-07 19:38:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure about slow node -- also, the point is to indicate that it CAN take up to 30+ minutes, not that it's the average. sudo is already used two lines further down, what do you mean by "new requirement"?'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-06-14 19:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Sorin Sbarnea <ssbarnea@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-06-14 19:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I will remove my downvote to avoid slowing you down in finding a fix. I do not use that code anywhere.

This is a function so in theory anyone can use it, even without sudo access. 

This makes me think that adding sudo here for all platforms could break some users which may not need/have sudo.

Maybe you could do a conditonal to perform a sudo only on suse?'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-06-24 18:10:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Read ntp.conf as root to avoid permission issues

The ntp.conf on opensuse is 640 root:ntp, so a normal jenkins/stack
user can not read it. With this patch it is possible to retrieve
the ntp server settings.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-09 10:56:46.000000000', 'message': 'Do not symlink the __pycache__ directory into the venv

If a service is already started it will create files in the venv
__pycache__ directory. This role will then try to symlink the non empty
directory to the host, which will fail.

"the directory /openstack/venvs/nova-19.1.0.dev272/lib/python3.6/
site-packages/__pycache__ is not empty, refusing to convert it"

This patch stops any __pycache__ files from being symlinked to the
venv, these appear to be present in suse packages [1].

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/773974/

Change-Id: Ib718f5de4e5ae5b401858dea6437e0039b7082e0
'}]
commit_message:
Do not symlink the __pycache__ directory into the venv

If a service is already started it will create files in the venv
__pycache__ directory. This role will then try to symlink the non empty
directory to the host, which will fail.

"the directory /openstack/venvs/nova-19.1.0.dev272/lib/python3.6/
site-packages/__pycache__ is not empty, refusing to convert it"

This patch stops any __pycache__ files from being symlinked to the
venv, these appear to be present in suse packages [1].

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/773974/

Change-Id: Ib718f5de4e5ae5b401858dea6437e0039b7082e0

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-04 17:02:16.000000000', 'message': 'Timeout connections when watching K8s API

Turns out that without `timeout` parameter, resources library is unable
to see connection interruption if those were "silent" (i.e. firewall
blocked the connection for a period long enough for K8s API to drop the
connection). This can be fixed by adding the `timeout` parameter to the
`requests.get()` invocation in `watch()` and retrying on receiving
`requests.ReadTimeout` exception.

This commit does so by setting the connection and read timeouts to 30
and 60 respectively and implementing the retry logic using last seen
resourceVersion to restart the watching connection.

Change-Id: I19df95aaae404b5a936c469085b1f80f9eb99e2e
Closes-Bug: 1842689
'}, {'created': '2019-09-04 17:23:21.000000000', 'message': 'Timeout connections when watching K8s API

connection). This can be fixed by adding the `timeout` parameter to the
`requests.get()` invocation in `watch()` and retrying on receiving
`requests.ReadTimeout` exception.

This commit does so by setting the connection and read timeouts to 30
and 60 respectively and implementing the retry logic using last seen

connection). This can be fixed by adding the `timeout` parameter to the
`requests.get()` invocation in `watch()` and retrying on receiving
`requests.ReadTimeout` exception.

This commit does so by setting the connection and read timeouts to 30
and 60 respectively and implementing the retry logic using last seen
resourceVersion to restart the watching connection.

commit_message:
Timeout connections when watching K8s API

Turns out that without `timeout` parameter, requests library is unable
to see connection interruption if those were "silent" (i.e. firewall
blocked the connection for a period long enough for K8s API to drop the
connection). This can be fixed by adding the `timeout` parameter to the
`requests.get()` invocation in `watch()` and retrying on receiving
`requests.ReadTimeout` exception.

This commit does so by setting the connection and read timeouts to 30
and 60 respectively and implementing the retry logic using last seen
resourceVersion to restart the watching connection.

Change-Id: I19df95aaae404b5a936c469085b1f80f9eb99e2e
Closes-Bug: 1842689

commit_message:
Veth pair "IFLA_LINK" populated since kernel 4.15.0-60-generic

Since kernel_version=4.15.0-60-generic, "iproute2" provides the veth
pair index, even if the pair interface is in other namespace. In
previous versions, the parameter 'IFLA_LINK' was not present. We need
to handle both cases

NOTE: this patch is merged in master combined with another bug
resolution [1] due to the existing problems in the CI. However, this
patch can be pushed alone in stable releases.

Conflicts:
        neutron/tests/functional/privileged/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/680001/

Change-Id: Id161423737189bf822716be953c0db9c1f09589d
Closes-Bug: #1842482
(cherry picked from commit fc2a4becd04cf951c0de2ad66ddaa3bbf73f20e3)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Implement maxUnavailable value for all LMA components
for rolling updates

-Set maxUnavailable value to 100% for daemonsets in each LMA chart
-Set maxUnavailable value to 50% for deployments in each LMA chart
-Statefulsets are exempt from this implementation

Change-Id: If5361bffb3b67778387910037251e07f1efca77c

commit_message:
libvirt: Mock libvirt'y things in setUp

While addressing a nit from change
I8e5a122cc547222249973cf595d90c2d8d5658d4, I realized pretty much every
test using the nova.tests.functional.libvirt.base.ServersTestBase' base
class was now mocking the same things. This results in a lot of noise
and distracts from what the tests are trying to do. Centralize the
common mocks in the base class and clean up said noise.

Change-Id: I5895865751e8e1fb08b3515bc9f8119cfcb9f35e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Honor trash_output when not using queue

Previously, trash_output was not honored if a queue was not being used
to post messages.

This patch changes the behavior so that trash_output will be honored
even if a queue is not being used, and all stdout/stderr will be
discarded.

Change-Id: I4fccfa0cb2a5382a52d63598f66dae446ff29c25
Closes-Bug: #1842102
(cherry picked from commit c7d44bc2ca67c40098982c88e9625aacd25b780d)

commit_message:
Add exclusions to the unused param warning

This adds the ability for us to specifically exclude some patterns of
parameters from the warning that is generated during the deployment for
unused heat params. The params being added are generated by the
deployment and not necessarily provided by the end user. The params
currently being excluded are:

 * '^(Docker|Container).*Image$' - container image vars
 * '^SwiftFetchDir(Get|Put)Tempurl$' - temp url for ceph
 * '^PythonInterpreter$' - python executable for the deploy

The warning message is also slightly adjusted to try and clarify that
the vars might be valid but not used due to service or deployment
configs.

Conflicts:
	tripleoclient/constants.py
	tripleoclient/workflows/parameters.py

Change-Id: Iad7d97346993b5c95443092b81d056293cdad752
Closes-Bug: #1842754
(cherry picked from commit b25a9a953bfe6923cb855ca22e4f84e620241956)

tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario009-multinode-oooq-container failed due to rpm mirror issue
tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001 failed because of interface setup before deploy steps'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-09-07 14:15:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-06 11:51:53.000000000', 'message': "HA: fix <service>_restart_bundle with minor update workflow

For each HA service we have a paunch container <service>_restart_bundle
which is started by paunch whenever config files changes during stack
deploy/update. This container runs a pcs command on a single node to
restart all the service's containers (e.g. all galera on all controllers).
By design, when it is run, configs have already been regenerated by the
deploy tasks on all nodes.

For minor updates, the workflow runs differently: all the steps of the
deploy tasks are run one node after the other, so when
<service>_restart_bundle is called, there is no guarantee that the
service's configs have been regenerated on all the nodes yet.

To fix the wrong restart behaviour, only restart local containers when
running during a minor update. And run once per node. When the minor
update workflow calls <service>_restart_container, we still have the
guarantee that the config files are already regenerated locally.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>
Co-Authored-By: Luca Miccini <lmiccini@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I92d4ddf2feeac06ce14468ae928c283f3fd04f45
Closes-Bug: #1841629
(manually cherry picked from commit 7f785e87579e0beaaa325e479d8387dc288c08ea)
"}]
commit_message:
HA: fix <service>_restart_bundle with minor update workflow

For each HA service we have a paunch container <service>_restart_bundle
which is started by paunch whenever config files changes during stack
deploy/update. This container runs a pcs command on a single node to
restart all the service's containers (e.g. all galera on all controllers).
By design, when it is run, configs have already been regenerated by the
deploy tasks on all nodes.

For minor updates, the workflow runs differently: all the steps of the
deploy tasks are run one node after the other, so when
<service>_restart_bundle is called, there is no guarantee that the
service's configs have been regenerated on all the nodes yet.

To fix the wrong restart behaviour, only restart local containers when
running during a minor update. And run once per node. When the minor
update workflow calls <service>_restart_container, we still have the
guarantee that the config files are already regenerated locally.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>
Co-Authored-By: Luca Miccini <lmiccini@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I92d4ddf2feeac06ce14468ae928c283f3fd04f45
Closes-Bug: #1841629
(manually cherry picked from commit 7f785e87579e0beaaa325e479d8387dc288c08ea)

commit_message:
Add exclusions to the unused param warning

This adds the ability for us to specifically exclude some patterns of
parameters from the warning that is generated during the deployment for
unused heat params. The params being added are generated by the
deployment and not necessarily provided by the end user. The params
currently being excluded are:

 * '^(Docker|Container).*Image$' - container image vars
 * '^SwiftFetchDir(Get|Put)Tempurl$' - temp url for ceph
 * '^PythonInterpreter$' - python executable for the deploy

The warning message is also slightly adjusted to try and clarify that
the vars might be valid but not used due to service or deployment
configs.

Conflicts:
	tripleoclient/constants.py
	tripleoclient/workflows/parameters.py
Change-Id: Iad7d97346993b5c95443092b81d056293cdad752
Closes-Bug: #1842754
(cherry picked from commit b25a9a953bfe6923cb855ca22e4f84e620241956)

commit_message:
Use a different wheel build venv per python executable

In a mixed py2/py3 setup the repo server currently tries to use
the same wheel build venv for both py2 and py3.

Change-Id: I70d3430cda52bf96c5e5f3b46ac3907375507f5c

commit_message:
Paginate over usage list to return all usages

since nova api 2.40 the os-simple-tenant-usage API supports pagination
and will by default return a number of entities configured internally in
Nova.
This means that when there are many enough projects,
the single call to usage.list() will not return usages for all projects.

This patch effectively copy-pastes the logic to paginate over usage list
results from novaclient/v2/shell.py code.

Change-Id: I1b639fe386b7b7db3223f6965495094b9d51533a
Story: #2005099
Task: #29713

commit_message:
Fix default region name definition

This commit sets the default value of the region_name to 'None' in the
config, this way its avoided the use of a region name
that might not exists on the OpenStack cloud.

Closes-Bug: 1843194
Change-Id: Ic9deca9cb073b5458f5aa063f669b30ae2568f30
(cherry picked from commit 027247329dcbcc300ebbc29f5571ddb8574cd1cf)

[{'created': '2019-09-06 20:10:32.000000000', 'message': "Ensure that VNC only binds on the internal network

When the VNC server is set to bind to 0.0.0.0,
unauthenticated console access is possible to any
VM via any of the compute host's interfaces. This
access should be restricted to an internal network.

Change-Id: Ibbc12ae282320f966eec90e9116388233e65eb9a
Closes-Bug: #1843004
(cherry picked from commit 82c5027814577535ba3db479e8e45a39548f4105)

commit_message:
Ensure that VNC only binds on the internal network

When the VNC server is set to bind to 0.0.0.0,
unauthenticated console access is possible to any
VM via any of the compute host's interfaces. This
access should be restricted to an internal network.

Change-Id: Ibbc12ae282320f966eec90e9116388233e65eb9a
Closes-Bug: #1843004
(cherry picked from commit 82c5027814577535ba3db479e8e45a39548f4105)

commit_message:
Microversion 2.78 - show server topology

Add support microversion 2.78 which adds server topology
information in the output of the following new command:

  nova server-topology

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/621476/
Change-Id: I6467d52d2528a37348458baf4842b571a97f3ed2
Implements: blueprint show-server-numa-topology

commit_message:
Replace coremask with cpu_list in vrouter schema

Actually contrail_vrouter_dpdk takes cpu_list
parameter, see ContrailVrouterDpdk class.

Change-Id: I956ed91af627cb02f7117fd69b36dfce12734c45
(cherry picked from commit e8e61573629907846776db1063fb783d6c108525)

[{'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-07 15:45:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-08-07 15:46:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-07 16:47:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Fantastic, thanks a lot!  I'll do a proper review later.  For now just wanted to note that I think this should probably go under a new doc/source/testing/ subdirectory, not under doc/source/eris/ since IIUC it's not specific to eris.

Also you will need to add it to the index to avoid the current failure:

2019-08-07 15:54:24.386532 | ubuntu-bionic | Warning, treated as error:
2019-08-07 15:54:24.386727 | ubuntu-bionic | /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/self-healing-sig/doc/source/eris/tools-list.rst:document isn't included in any toctree

You can test this locally yourself simply by running tox."}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-08 12:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-09 11:00:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I've just added as reviewers several people who I think might be interested in this list.  Not necessarily asking for your review, just an FYI that this list now exists :)  Nicely rendered version is here:

https://logs.opendev.org/38/675138/2/check/openstack-tox-docs/32b64f2/html/testing/tools-list.html

It looks great to me, and gives us a better picture of the whole landscape.  I would love to see this in matrix form too, so that the gaps and overlapping areas are visually clearer, but this is a great start.  Ihtisham, are you able to draw any conclusions or make observations based on your research so far?"}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-09 11:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Oh also, please can you add the following to the commit message?

Story: 2002129
Task: 35628

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-08-09 11:04:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-08-09 11:17:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-08-09 11:19:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

well done'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-08-09 11:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-09 18:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 20207, 'date': '2019-08-09 18:45:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Good list of tools.'}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-09 19:04:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks very much for the review Adam and Bogdan. I have added a tools matrix with some major features, if you think there could be some more features with which we can differentiate more, please let me know.

Yes, I would appreciate if more people can review this, as I don't have hands on experience with these tools yet, so I may have missed many of its features.

As for my current observation I can't really say much as I am right now trying out Rally testing on cloud and trying to run what Eris has implemented. 

For control plane and destructive testing Rally+OSfault already has been chosen. For data plane testing it looks like Shaker can help out there but I will still need to get some experience with it, which I will try out after control plane testing.

Scalability and concurrency testing are something which need study and experimentation to find tools can be good candidates for that."}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-09 22:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-09 22:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Great work - the matrix is especially helpful!'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2019-08-10 05:26:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Nice :)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-08-12 09:30:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-12 16:04:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-08-13 12:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16353, 'date': '2019-08-13 15:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

sorry for commenting late. Nice job.'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2019-08-14 03:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-14 09:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Ihtisham this is looking great to me now.  The only thing which still might be worth adding is a brief introduction giving some context about why the self-healing SIG cares about this information, why it's in our repo, and what we hope to do with it longer term.  The context is already documented in the linked story https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2002129 and https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/extreme-testing-contacts so we would just need to paraphrase that.

Does that make sense, and if so, would you prefer to do it or would you like me to?  I don't mind either way."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-08-14 09:23:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-14 10:08:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

> Does that make sense, and if so, would you prefer to do it or would
 > you like me to?  I don't mind either way.

Totally make sense to give it a context, I can do that."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-14 10:09:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

I like this. Maybe worth cleaning the trailing whitespaces.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-14 11:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

This is really nice table and very valuable for operators to select the testing tooling.

few comments.

May be we can place this info in lot other place also like QA doc etc.'}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-27 18:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 30772, 'date': '2019-08-27 18:27:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-28 09:42:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-28 09:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

This is looking fantastic now.  I just pushed PS7 to tidy up a few minor nits but I think we can merge this today so that it gets published at https://docs.openstack.org/self-healing-sig/latest/, and then ask for reviews from the mentioned projects before announcing it to the whole community.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-08-28 09:48:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15834, 'date': '2019-08-28 09:53:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2019-08-28 17:12:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-08-28 17:17:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-08-29 16:50:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

[{'created': '2019-06-14 03:36:38.000000000', 'message': '[PoC] Enable creating pdf doc

The is one of community goals that each project could produce a
single PDF file. There is no requirement to update repo to allow
local building of PDFs, the doc gate job will run and produce PDFs
for all projects.

Since there is no further details about how the final implementation
looks like, as such, this is a PoC to reveal issues during typesetting.

To build PDF locally, tex package is required, following is recommended:

* inkscape
* texlive-latex-base
* texlive-latex-extra
* texlive-fonts-recommended

More about the goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/pdf-doc-generation.html

Change-Id: Iade8e60f5e272d70b2bbfdcd8429a19e1f95f365

commit_message:
Build pdf doc

The is one of community goals that each project could produce a
single PDF file. The pdf should be in the output of openstack-tox-docs
job.

TeX packages are required to build PDF locally, following is recommended:

* inkscape
* texlive-latex-base
* texlive-latex-extra
* texlive-fonts-recommended

More about the goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/pdf-doc-generation.html
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/train-pdf-support-goal
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/pdf-goal-train-common-problems

Change-Id: Iade8e60f5e272d70b2bbfdcd8429a19e1f95f365

commit_message:
Support for metrics description

This patch adds the capability to add a description for the ipmi
metrics.

The description are based on [1]

[1] https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/servers/ipmi/ipmi-second-gen-interface-spec-v2-rev1-1.html

Change-Id: Ic21a778b06456140ac5dbbec0e44271c72d80b29

[{'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-06-14 04:02:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-06-14 06:50:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

thanks Kaifeng, one comment inline'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-06-14 06:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-06-14 06:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-06-14 06:57:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

got you! :D
the good thing is this actually works, at least for the specs repos
doing tests in other repos (ironic, ironic-inspector) unfortunately don't give the same good result :/"}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-06-14 07:07:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> got you! :D
 > the good thing is this actually works, at least for the specs repos
 > doing tests in other repos (ironic, ironic-inspector) unfortunately
 > don't give the same good result :/

The doc structure is relatively simple, so I start from them, yes it works, actually I had used sphinx to manage notes for a while, and generated PDFs. However, it appears our docs are too complex to generate a proper PDF, I have noted some in the whiteboard under the section you created.

We can convert the SVG to PNG, but for Cross Referencing and Verbatim, I am not sure we have any means, because we rely sphinx while latex customization is taken control by openstackdocstheme, I suspect there is little we can do at the project level."}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-09-05 05:48:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-09-05 08:49:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

I can't imagine who would read specs in a pdf, but it looks nice, so why not. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-09-09 14:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

[{'created': '2019-09-09 12:38:09.000000000', 'message': 'DNM WIP stop conditional tagging and remove retax x86 containers

As tracked by tripleo-ci squad in [1] we are creating and pushing
manifests with name format {{ container_name }}:{{ full_hash }}

So we must simultaneously stop create + push x86 containers the way
we currently do [2], since there is a clash for the name of the
container and the manifest.

Unconditionally create and push all containers with the name format
{{ container_name }}:{{ full_hash }}_{{ ansible_architecture }}
and remove the now defunct retagging.

[1] https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1270
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663977

commit_message:
DNM WIP stop conditional tagging and remove retag x86 containers

As tracked by tripleo-ci squad in [1] we are creating and pushing
manifests with name format {{ container_name }}:{{ full_hash }}

So we must simultaneously stop create + push x86 containers the way
we currently do [2], since there is a clash for the name of the
container and the manifest.

Unconditionally create and push all containers with the name format
{{ container_name }}:{{ full_hash }}_{{ ansible_architecture }}
and remove the now defunct retagging.

[1] https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1270
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663977

Change-Id: I6a7d1b6954c06bd53ba26be23f645218993e8e7e

commit_message:
Remove cluster floating_ip_enabled default value

There shouldn't be a default value for floating_ip_enabled when creating
cluster. By default, when it's not set, the cluster's floating_ip_enabled
attribute should be set with the value of cluster template. It's fixed
by removing the default value from Magnum API.

Task: 36500
Story: 2006208

Change-Id: I4077783c6a19a413d534f77f287da587353df0af

commit_message:
Use trash_output in create_admin_via_ssh workflow

When deploying a large amount of nodes, the create_admin_via_ssh
workflow could fail due to the large amount of ansible output generated.

This patch updates the tripleo.ansible-playbook action in the workflow
with trash_output:true so that the output is not saved in the mistral
DB.

There is a log file saved already in case the output is needed for debug
purposes.

Change-Id: I078b22fb0a0e7116f87419b444b8b4039db73ef8
Closes-Bug: #1842102

commit_message:
Fix designate config

The changes in [0] sadly were almost, but not quite, completely broken.
They introduced config options that do not exist in designate and also
made secrets being saved into the node config.

Fix all this, also clean up the remainder of a workaround that is no
longer needed.

This was partially fixed for stable/queens in [1], amended the
cherry-pick accordingly.

Conflicts:
	recipes/common.rb

[0] If4e185eb58a525e22971c7a8b876274c353db847
[1] https://review.opendev.org/606094

Change-Id: I5ccb4fa5d8f3a003c4dd1b07e1c9ab2a99246dd6
(cherry picked from commit be2fd380fa50bd1701fe416e6874142749d424fa)

and a pod without waiting for Kuryr generated resources,
which is the actual behavior expected by the user.

an extra column, stating whether the cell is enabled or not. This means
that the regex never matches, so existing_cells is always empty.

This fix updates the regex by adding a match group for this field which

Unfortuately the CLI doesn't output in JSON format, which would make

Change-Id: Ib6400b33785f3ef674bffc9329feb3e33bd3f9a3

commit_message:
Fix Nova cell search

The output from `nova-manage cell_v2 list_cells --verbose` contains
an extra column, stating whether the cell is enabled or not. This means
that the regex never matches, so existing_cells is always empty.

This fix updates the regex by adding a match group for this field which
may be used in a later change.

Unfortuately the CLI doesn't output in JSON format, which would make
this a lot less messy.

Closes-Bug: #1842460
Change-Id: Ib6400b33785f3ef674bffc9329feb3e33bd3f9a3

commit_message:
Ensure LBaaS state is updated upon SVC deletion

When a SVC is recreated all the LBaaS resources are first deleted,
which requires the LBaaS state obj to be updated accordingly, then
created. Right now, when a LBaaS deletion happens the values for
members, pools and listeners are not updated on the lbaas state obj.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring the lbaas state object is
updated.

Closes-Bug: 1843142
Change-Id: Ibe72cb3ebd3d2a861684e7e8ac5a310fe8060aa9

commit_message:
[RHEL8]Set venv_python_executable to python3

Since in RHEL-8, all stuff is tested using python3 but
in python_venv_build role venv_python_executable var defaults to
python2 leading to venv getting created to python2.

So setting the same distro specific var fixes the issue.

Change-Id: Iab4e9f9764c12ccf7536995920a21177aa1d6cda
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Derives NUMA aware vSwitches parameters

Derives the NUMA aware vSwitches parameters NeutronPhysnetNUMANodesMapping
and NeutronTunnelNUMANodes automatically using host introspection.

Change-Id: Ia3a55ec158b16485cd3ffa56d4931b73502a1058
Closes-Bug: #1797925

[{'created': '2019-09-04 08:53:35.000000000', 'message': 'SELinux: correct type for /var/log/containers

The correct type for this directory is "container_file_t" (or
svirt_sandbox_file_t). The var_log_t was needed before in order to allow
syslog to write HAProxy logs in /var/log/containers/haproxy.

This is not needed anymore, since a patch in openstack-selinux[1] allows
syslog to have a full access to container_file_t type.
Moreover, since we have logrotate running in a container, it mounts the
/var/log/containers location with ":z" flag, which re-labels all the
files to container_file_t.

[1] https://github.com/redhat-openstack/openstack-selinux/commit/f9b45cede356c0e09f78ffb8a3c01fb80b6aac36

Change-Id: I13a90695686b9134f6fcceac1bf6d22c2ac390a5
'}]
commit_message:
SELinux: correct type for /var/log/containers

The correct type for this directory is "container_file_t" (or
svirt_sandbox_file_t). The var_log_t was needed before in order to allow
syslog to write HAProxy logs in /var/log/containers/haproxy.

This is not needed anymore, since a patch in openstack-selinux[1] allows
syslog to have a full access to container_file_t type.
Moreover, since we have logrotate running in a container, it mounts the
/var/log/containers location with ":z" flag, which re-labels all the
files to container_file_t.

[1] https://github.com/redhat-openstack/openstack-selinux/commit/f9b45cede356c0e09f78ffb8a3c01fb80b6aac36

Change-Id: I13a90695686b9134f6fcceac1bf6d22c2ac390a5

Fix bug in recordset status

This patch changes the status handling of record sets
to always report the appropriate status.

Closes-Bug: #1842994

commit_message:
Fix workflow language tests after updating jsonschema to 3.0.2

* The new version of jsonschema (3.0.2) considers numbers written
  as XXX.0 (an integer but written using the form of float numbers)
  integers. Whereas the previous versions didn't. So we have to
  fix the tests that expected an error in this case when validating
  the syntax of the policies.

Change-Id: Ifc36f4a1f6126d6cbde2424fd88967c04d84185a

'}]
commit_message:
Add pdf-docs env to tox.ini

- Enable PDF documentation. Based on [1].
- Enable table of contents generation for pdf
- Removed literalinclude of designate.conf [2]
- Removed illegal character (a literal ESC)
- Fix incorrect column count in backends summary section
- Replace nodes.line() with nodes.paragraph()

[1] https://review.opendev.org/601659
[2] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/3099

Change-Id: Ie454f8f9ebc8e36347ce33b22f2e6da0257fe4e0
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@suse.com>

commit_message:
Build pdf doc

The is one of community goals that each project could produce a
single PDF file. The pdf should be in the output of openstack-tox-docs
job.

TeX packages are required to build PDF locally, following is recommended:

* inkscape
* texlive-latex-base
* texlive-latex-extra
* texlive-fonts-recommended

More about the goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/pdf-doc-generation.html
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/train-pdf-support-goal
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/pdf-goal-train-common-problems

Change-Id: Id2244fa8c70e8b8c09e309998012041883b98ab1
(cherry picked from commit 386d5df55778459bfde22488dfd9bba3659b547f)

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: Icce6506a61590240e8a320146ef2648837173ca1
Story: #2005924
Task: #34214

commit_message:
Fix default region name definition

This commit sets the default value of the region_name to 'None' in the
config, this way its avoided the use of a region name
that might not exists on the OpenStack cloud.

Closes-Bug: 1843194
Change-Id: Ic9deca9cb073b5458f5aa063f669b30ae2568f30

commit_message:
NEC Driver: Support to report discard parameter

The patch adds discard parameter to connector object. The driver sets
True if the volume is thin-provisioned, otherwise False.

Change-Id: I4922cf82e2811a2bf579f275ca70061cf299ed78

Fail fast if local clone is missing on include-gate-changes.sh

Improves output and avoids delayed failure due to performing an invalid
replacement using sed.

[{'created': '2019-08-28 08:37:04.000000000', 'message': "Add else statement when running leapp without SKIP_DEVEL.

If leapp_unsubscribed is set to false, the condition won't be
met and the environment variable won't be included. However,
Ansible complains that there is no else statement and the task
fails: the inline if-expression on line 2 evaluated to false and n
o else section was defined. Adding the else statemnt to include
an empty string to solve the issue.

Change-Id: I8a52da5ca81e61a9dd5f39997535965a75a5abba
"}, {'created': '2019-09-02 14:50:33.000000000', 'message': "Add else statement when running leapp without SKIP_DEVEL.

If leapp_unsubscribed is set to false, the condition won't be
met and the environment variable won't be included. However,
Ansible complains that there is no else statement and the task
fails: the inline if-expression on line 2 evaluated to false and n
o else section was defined. Adding the else statemnt to include
an empty string to solve the issue.

Change-Id: I8a52da5ca81e61a9dd5f39997535965a75a5abba
"}, {'created': '2019-09-06 13:24:21.000000000', 'message': "Add else statement when running leapp without SKIP_DEVEL.

If leapp_unsubscribed is set to false, the condition won't be
met and the environment variable won't be included. However,
Ansible complains that there is no else statement and the task
fails: the inline if-expression on line 2 evaluated to false and n

Change-Id: I8a52da5ca81e61a9dd5f39997535965a75a5abba
"}]
commit_message:
Add else statement when running leapp without SKIP_DEVEL.

If leapp_unsubscribed is set to false, the condition won't be
met and the environment variable won't be included. However,
Ansible complains that there is no else statement and the task
fails: the inline if-expression on line 2 evaluated to false and n
o else section was defined. Adding the else statemnt to include
an empty string to solve the issue.

Change-Id: I8a52da5ca81e61a9dd5f39997535965a75a5abba

commit_message:
Use memcached for token caching in ironic inspector authtoken

Use memcached to cache token in ironic inspector authtoken,
as in-process cache, which we currently use, was already
deprecated[1].

Also, add unit tests for ironic inspector related manifests.

[1] Ied2b88c8cefe5655a88d0c2f334de04e588fa75a

Change-Id: I13efecb6b1900b9062e46ab5bef7f15790ab668f

[{'created': '2019-06-21 08:54:43.000000000', 'message': "API microversion 2.74: Add 'power-update' external event

The 2.74 microversion adds the 'power-update' server
external event to the os-server-external-events API.

This is an admin-only API by default and this event is
currently only used by Ironic as part of updating the
power-state of a physical instance, and therefore does not
have any CLI or python API binding impacts in the client.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/645611/
Part of blueprint nova-support-instance-power-update
Story: 2004969
Task: 34271

commit_message:
API microversion 2.76: Add 'power-update' external event

The 2.76 microversion adds the 'power-update' server
external event to the os-server-external-events API.

This is an admin-only API by default and this event is
currently only used by Ironic as part of updating the
power-state of a physical instance, and therefore does not
have any CLI or python API binding impacts in the client.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/645611/
Part of blueprint nova-support-instance-power-update
Story: 2004969
Task: 34271

Change-Id: I1f5de90e19b7b13c7746fea8bbdf8e09bcb92cff

commit_message:
Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: Id7220a68d7f4f544801ad9551021c6b2ade493ac
Sem-Ver: feature

subject: Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train
messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-09-09 08:58:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-07 18:27:53.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7545d56f083a87d652af0b317d37efb389acb62a
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7545d56f083a87d652af0b317d37efb389acb62a

commit_message:
Adds job to run inspector in non-standalone mode

The job uses memcached for coordination backend, etcd3gw still has issue
on retrieving members.

Story: 2001842
Task: 30376

Change-Id: I76c359d6835e435968cbfb1a3f4318e73f0203ec

We can only promote content when it was generated, so add the same file

'}]
commit_message:
Add file matcher to releasenotes promote job

We can only promote content when it was generated, so add the same file
matcher to the promote job that the gate job uses.

Change-Id: I67a94af985580574adb00571abc61e3697bcd465

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-27 10:23:43.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Add delete_on_termination to volume-attach API

Support add 'delete_on_termination' field to the voume attach API to support
configuring whether to delete the data volume when the instance is destroyed.

While attaching a volume to a shelved offloaded server, the BDM is created in
the API service. To avoid issues with trying to attach a volume with
'delete_on_termination=true' to a server running on an older compute service,
the implementation should just set the field in the API rather than the
compute service.

Change-Id: I55731b1822a4e32909665a2872d80895cb5b12f7
Implements: blueprint support-delete-on-termination-in-server-attach-volume

commit_message:
Add delete_on_termination to volume-attach API

Add the 'delete_on_termination' field to the volume attach API to support
configuring whether to delete the data volume when the instance is destroyed.

To avoid upgrade impact issues with older computes, the
'delete_on_termination' field is set in the API rather than when the BDM
is created in the compute service.

Implements: blueprint support-delete-on-termination-in-server-attach-volume
Change-Id: I55731b1822a4e32909665a2872d80895cb5b12f7

commit_message:
Add response schema validation for volume transfer

This is to add response schema validation for volume transfer.
Besides, created_at should be removed from the response example of
"List volume transfers for a project" in api ref,
I52a81454a995920c1ba5534fea3d50f6c9986881 will fix them.

Change-Id: If31470dac38d7f08768f43fa77bd018a932f0313
partially-implements: blueprint volume-response-schema-validation

The devstack opensuse-150 nodeset went away[1] which is causing package
repo issues on the federation jobs. Update the nodeset to fix the jobs.

commit_message:
Fix federation CI

The devstack opensuse-150 nodeset went away[1] which is causing package
repo issues on the federation jobs. Update the nodeset to fix the jobs.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/667539

Change-Id: Icda90e0598383db0931a34dcede7fb4736fe195d

commit_message:
Add driver_name to deployable reported by fake driver.

Without this, cyborg_agent reports errors on loading
fake driver.

Change-Id: Id8e62a01adb588880086896b84efd767c118afba

commit_message:
Implement watcher datamodel list in watcherclient

1. Add data_model.py and data_model_shell.py for accept and
process request.

2. Add relative unittest.

Partically Implements: blueprint show-datamodel-api

Change-Id: I5e080453acaedf7e20734d67922b64511dd5f7fd

commit_message:
Add version verification during alias creation

When an alias is created based on a version number, Qinling doesn't
check if the version exist which could become an issue when the alias
is used by a webhook, job or an execution.

Change-Id: Icf6b81a4f4411f630abdcdd26d61205a0d39e015
Story: 2005838
Task: 33609

subject: Add remote_ip_prefix for SG SSH rule
messages:
[{'account_id': 10644, 'date': '2019-08-29 21:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-09-08 22:32:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Can you add a story that includes more information about the problem you are seeing?  For example a security group rule show of this security group when the remote-ip is not being set?
From my manual testing, the default for the remote-ip is already "0.0.0.0/0".'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-29 21:43:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add remote_ip_prefix for SG SSH rule

If you are running tempest against a remote openstack
deployment, and the SG SSH rule does not have the
remote_ip_prefix set, tests that require ssh-ing into
an instance will fail, example:
octavia_tempest_plugin.tests.scenario.v2.test_traffic_ops\
.TrafficOperationsScenarioTest.test_basic_traffic

Setting a remote_ip_prefix of 0.0.0.0/0 to the ssh security
group rule allows remote ssh access to instances,
and the test then passes.

Change-Id: I15c2c3c3ab23809607b7bb6b057ce43cdcbb67b0
'}]
commit_message:
Add remote_ip_prefix for SG SSH rule

If you are running tempest against a remote openstack
deployment, and the SG SSH rule does not have the
remote_ip_prefix set, tests that require ssh-ing into
an instance will fail, example:
octavia_tempest_plugin.tests.scenario.v2.test_traffic_ops\
.TrafficOperationsScenarioTest.test_basic_traffic

Setting a remote_ip_prefix of 0.0.0.0/0 to the ssh security
group rule allows remote ssh access to instances,
and the test then passes.

Change-Id: I15c2c3c3ab23809607b7bb6b057ce43cdcbb67b0

commit_message:
Mark Oracle ZFSSA Drivers Unsupported

I have been contacted by Iain MacDonnell at
Oracle indicating that they are removing support for
their Cinder driver.

As a result I am following our deprecation process and
marking the driver unsupported for the Train release
and it will be removed in the Ussuri release.

Change-Id: Id6181e0632a84d9538a34ac9460c36ba983a3757

commit_message:
Address review comments for MacroSAN driver

- Removing unnecessary os-brick code and refactor/optimize driver
- Solve the modifications made by the reviewer in the 19th and 20th
  patches in the driver of the initial join.
  Link:https://review.opendev.org/#/c/612311/

Closes-Bug: #1837920
Implements: blueprint macrosan-cinder-driver
Change-Id: I0a6b13941936cd9e8521e3fcbe8fb61d3da3c45c

commit_message:
Replace include_tasks with import_tasks

There are places when we have include_tasks in nested tasks. It means
that -t "tag_from_nested_task" won't work as all nested tasks will need
either "always" tag or should be "import_tasks" instead.

This patch replaces include_tasks with import_tasks for External steps
allowing to run

openstack overcloud external-update run --tags tag_from_nested_task
openstack overcloud external-upgrade run --tags tag_from_nested_task

without hacking all nested tasks.

cherry-pick not 100% clean, required to resolve conflicts due to big
difference between master and stable/stein.

Closes-Bug: #1842410

(manually cherry-picked from commit 74a1cd7d13c271a4b7f9732a129c09e2b22b3f41)

Change-Id: I51a148cdc5538d5a1106d58d227d361d1e6f9e19

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-26 13:50:48.000000000', 'message': 'Add warning log if auth_strategy is not keystone

A user came to the IRC channel with CLI errors:
"Client-side error: Validation failure: Missing project ID in
request where one is required."

The root cause was the [api_settings] auth_strategy was set to
"noauth" instead of "keystone".

This patch adds a warning log message to the API process that
warns users that typically the auth_strategy should be set to
keystone.
It also points the user to have an administrator check the keystone
settings in the octavia.conf.

Change-Id: I7793d7a9113b23ac88e7c53d5dc292a70b9453b5
(cherry picked from commit 48371c98ee49807b5c2b73a442d649bad40b73ec)
'}]
commit_message:
Add warning log if auth_strategy is not keystone

A user came to the IRC channel with CLI errors:
"Client-side error: Validation failure: Missing project ID in
request where one is required."

The root cause was the [api_settings] auth_strategy was set to
"noauth" instead of "keystone".

This patch adds a warning log message to the API process that
warns users that typically the auth_strategy should be set to
keystone.
It also points the user to have an administrator check the keystone
settings in the octavia.conf.

Change-Id: I7793d7a9113b23ac88e7c53d5dc292a70b9453b5
(cherry picked from commit 48371c98ee49807b5c2b73a442d649bad40b73ec)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-06 14:22:55.000000000', 'message': 'Honor trash_output when not using queue

Previously, trash_output was not honored if a queue was not being used
to post messages.

This patch changes the behavior so that trash_output will be honored
even if a queue is not being used, and all stdout/stderr will be
discarded.

Change-Id: I4fccfa0cb2a5382a52d63598f66dae446ff29c25
Closes-Bug: #1842102
(cherry picked from commit c7d44bc2ca67c40098982c88e9625aacd25b780d)
'}]
commit_message:
Honor trash_output when not using queue

Previously, trash_output was not honored if a queue was not being used
to post messages.

This patch changes the behavior so that trash_output will be honored
even if a queue is not being used, and all stdout/stderr will be
discarded.

Change-Id: I4fccfa0cb2a5382a52d63598f66dae446ff29c25
Closes-Bug: #1842102
(cherry picked from commit c7d44bc2ca67c40098982c88e9625aacd25b780d)

Nova allows rebuild of instance when vm_state is ERROR. [1]

The vm_state is restored to ACTIVE only restored after a successful build.

commit_message:
Fix rebuild of baremetal instance when vm_state is ERROR

Nova allows rebuild of instance when vm_state is ERROR. [1]

The vm_state is restored to ACTIVE only after a successful build.
This means rebuilding a baremetal instance using the Ironic driver
is impossible because wait_for_active fails if vm_state=ERROR is found.

This is a regression introduced in a previous change which added
the ability to delete an instance in spawning state. [2]

This present change will skip the abort installation logic
if task_state is REBUILD_SPAWNING while preserving the previous logic.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1183946
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1455000

Change-Id: I857ad7264f1a7ef1263d8a9d4eca491d6c8dce0f
Closes-bug: #1735009

commit_message:
Fix online data migrations

Online data migrations are part of the rolling upgrades mechanism, and
they are run on the current installed version before we upgrade to the
next one to ensure that all DB records have been upgraded even if they
have not been accessed during the life of the current release service
life.

This means that online migrations from one release should be removed on
the next release, as they are no longer needed.

We still have the Queens online data migrations in our code, and we
should remove them in master, Stein, and Rocky.

This patch also adds checks to the status tool to check that these
online data migrations have completed.

Closes-bug: #1837703
Change-Id: I025789f92eb318b8e5a531bea6cf106d52f268ae

commit_message:
Use memcached for token caching in authtoken

Use memcached to cache token in cinder authtoken, as in-process
cache, which we currently use, was already deprecated[1].

[1] Ied2b88c8cefe5655a88d0c2f334de04e588fa75a

Change-Id: Id65dd196880c60eadeb6f06fb2a8384084bf8755

commit_message:
Add tests for system member for trusts

For trusts, a system member is essentially the same as a system reader:
system members should not be able to create or delete trusts. This
change adds tests to assert that, but no policy changes are required to
account for the member role.

Change-Id: I0acd55f4428708430740bf2c305f664e199dd304
Partial-bug: #1818846
Related-Bug: #968696

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 20:45:08.000000000', 'message': 'Move delete_trust enforcement to default policies

Without this change, policy enforcement for the DELETE
/OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id} API is hardcoded in the flask dispatcher
code. This is a problem because this enforcement can't be controlled by
the operator, as is the norm. Moreover, it makes the transition to
system-scope and default-roles-aware policies more difficult because
there's no sensible migration from "" to a logical role-based check
string.

This converts the hardcoded enforcement to enforcement via default
policies for DELETE /OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}. The API code had been
making special exception for the is_admin context, which we need to
account for in the policy rule. This can be deprecated in a future patch
that makes the policies system-scope aware.

This change does not use the formal oslo.policy deprecation system
because "" OR'd with the new default is entirely useless as a policy.

Change-Id: I1aaba72b69b389ffbfcf7d5b8cc70453ffa59e73
Partial-bug: #1818850
Partial-bug: #1818846
'}, {'created': '2019-08-13 21:59:42.000000000', 'message': 'Move delete_trust enforcement to default policies

Without this change, policy enforcement for the DELETE
/OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id} API is hardcoded in the flask dispatcher
code. This is a problem because this enforcement can't be controlled by
the operator, as is the norm. Moreover, it makes the transition to
system-scope and default-roles-aware policies more difficult because
there's no sensible migration from "" to a logical role-based check
string.

This converts the hardcoded enforcement to enforcement via default
policies for DELETE /OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}. Currently only the
trustor or the is_admin user can access this API (since the is_admin
user bypasses the policy loading). This behavior will be changed in a
future patch that will allow the system admin to access this API.

This change does not use the formal oslo.policy deprecation system
because "" OR'd with the new default is entirely useless as a policy.

'}, {'created': '2019-08-13 22:28:35.000000000', 'message': 'Move delete_trust enforcement to default policies

Without this change, policy enforcement for the DELETE
/OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id} API is hardcoded in the flask dispatcher
code. This is a problem because this enforcement can't be controlled by
the operator, as is the norm. Moreover, it makes the transition to
system-scope and default-roles-aware policies more difficult because
there's no sensible migration from "" to a logical role-based check
string.

This converts the hardcoded enforcement to enforcement via default
policies for DELETE /OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}. Currently only the
trustor or the is_admin user can access this API (since the is_admin
user bypasses the policy loading). This behavior will be changed in a
future patch that will allow the system admin to access this API.

This change does not use the formal oslo.policy deprecation system
because "" OR'd with the new default is entirely useless as a policy.

commit_message:
Move delete_trust enforcement to default policies

Without this change, policy enforcement for the DELETE
/OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id} API is hardcoded in the flask dispatcher
code. This is a problem because this enforcement can't be controlled by
the operator, as is the norm. Moreover, it makes the transition to
system-scope and default-roles-aware policies more difficult because
there's no sensible migration from "" to a logical role-based check
string.

This converts the hardcoded enforcement to enforcement via default
policies for DELETE /OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}. Currently only the
trustor or the is_admin user can access this API (since the is_admin
user bypasses the policy loading). This behavior will be changed in a
future patch that will allow the system admin to access this API.

This change does not use the formal oslo.policy deprecation system
because "" OR'd with the new default is entirely useless as a policy.

Change-Id: I1aaba72b69b389ffbfcf7d5b8cc70453ffa59e73
Partial-bug: #1818850
Partial-bug: #1818846

[{'created': '2019-05-23 17:47:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix OVS build issue on Fedora

Seems later versions of Fedora with 5.x kernels no longer have
kernel package names with the kernel version, just 'kernel-devel'
and 'kernel-headers'. Try to take this into account here by only
appending '-VERSION' when necessary.

This is breaking one of the networking-ovn repos periodic jobs.

Change-Id: Ia9cc8f3ee11802f51317eb0e7c82fadd1c15c4b4
Closes-bug: #1830248

commit_message:
Fix OVS build issue on Fedora

No longer build the OVS kernel modules when installing from
source. This was added when OVS didn't support conntrack,
which hasn't been the case for a while.

This is breaking one of the networking-ovn repos periodic jobs.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/680066/
Change-Id: Ia9cc8f3ee11802f51317eb0e7c82fadd1c15c4b4
Closes-bug: #1830248

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-16 01:49:39.000000000', 'message': 'Implement system reader role for trusts API

Currently, the trusts API only allows the "project" scope type, and
moreover inconsistently enforces different actions based on admin status
or trustor/trustee relationship: for example, an "admin" can list all
trusts but not filter by trustor or trustee and cannot get details for a
single trust, not can they list or get trust roles. This patch changes
the behavior of the trusts API to allow a system reader to list and get

trustee could do so. This helps make the different actions in the trusts
API consistent with one another and makes the API more useful to a
deployment auditor. A subsequent patch will add system admin
functionality.

commit_message:
Implement system reader role for trusts API

Currently, the trusts API only allows the "project" scope type, and
moreover inconsistently enforces different actions based on admin status
or trustor/trustee relationship: for example, an "admin" can list all
trusts but not filter by trustor or trustee and cannot get details for a
single trust, not can they list or get trust roles. This patch changes
the behavior of the trusts API to allow a system reader to list and get
details for trusts and trust roles, where previously only a trustor or
trustee could do so. This helps make the different actions in the trusts
API consistent with one another and makes the API more useful to a
deployment auditor. A subsequent patch will add system admin
functionality.

This change does not use the oslo.policy deprecation feature for the
'identity:list_trusts_for_trustor' or 'identity:list_trusts_for_trustee'
policies as those are new policies introduced in 7717ed3.

Change-Id: I4e1482643e18fd46e937ffae8b3623cea2d2dd62
Partial-bug: #1818850
Partial-bug: #1818846
Related-Bug: #968696

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 23:13:03.000000000', 'message': 'Move get_role_for_trust enforcement to policies

Without this change, policy enforcement for the GET
/OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}/roles/{role_id} API is hardcoded in the
flask dispatcher code. This is a problem because this enforcement can't
be controlled by the operator, as is the norm. Moreover, it makes the
transition to system-scope and default-roles-aware policies more
difficult because there's no sensible migration from "" to a logical
role-based check string.

This converts the hardcoded enforcement to enforcement via default
policies for GET /OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}/roles/{role_id}. The API
specifically blocks the is_admin user from using it, and since policies
aren't loaded for the is_admin user we need to continue explicitly
blocking it.

This change does not use the formal oslo.policy deprecation system
because "" OR'd with the new default is entirely useless as a policy.

Change-Id: Ib5a6a87313aa7b2a73211f512b8a8c675a21b52f
Partial-bug: #1818850
Partial-bug: #1818846

commit_message:
Move get_role_for_trust enforcement to policies

Without this change, policy enforcement for the GET
/OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}/roles/{role_id} API is hardcoded in the
flask dispatcher code. This is a problem because this enforcement can't
be controlled by the operator, as is the norm. Moreover, it makes the
transition to system-scope and default-roles-aware policies more
difficult because there's no sensible migration from "" to a logical
role-based check string.

This converts the hardcoded enforcement to enforcement via default
policies for GET /OS-TRUST/trusts/{trust_id}/roles/{role_id}. The API
specifically blocks the is_admin user from using it, and since policies
aren't loaded for the is_admin user we need to continue explicitly
blocking it.

This change does not use the formal oslo.policy deprecation system
because "" OR'd with the new default is entirely useless as a policy.

Change-Id: Ib5a6a87313aa7b2a73211f512b8a8c675a21b52f
Partial-bug: #1818850
Partial-bug: #1818846
